title: Who operates the world's biggest data centers - Google, Amazon, Netflix, the NSA, someone else? - Quora

response.answer_text: I worked at AWS S3 and now I’m working at Google Cloud, so I had to chance to get a feel of the scale these companies operate at. It’s mind blowing. Interesting fact - Google is quite open about DC capacities to its workers, you could literally look up how much CPU, memory, GPU, etc. exist at which DC. But of course, it’s prohibited to share this knowledge. I’m not sure if Amazon is not as open or just doesn’t have such tools, but I didn’t see an easy way to check DCs locations, capacities and load. I just had a chance to deploy software there and get a feel of their scale. As I’m not allowed to tell actual numbers, I’ll be using public data and just general knowledge. Let’s think logically. Here’s what Google made public: Data center locations. And here’s Amazon’s one: Global Infrastructure. I don’t think government agencies have or, actually, need so much compute and storage power as commercial companies. Plus, I suspect government just uses commercial data centers for some things. E.g. take a look here: US Federal Government in the Cloud - Amazon Web Services (AWS). Also, I don’t know much about Chinese internal cloud or other countries. I assume it’s impressive, but let’s look at the rest of the world. And the only 3d major player in cloud I could think of is Microsoft Datacenter Infrastructure | Microsoft. So, let’s concentrate on Amazon, Google and Microsoft. Now, Amazon controls around 37% of cloud, Microsoft 29% and Google 17%. Don’t be fooled by low number for Google - it’s a new player in cloud and most of DC resources are used for it’s enormous products like Search, Gmail, etc. Same for Microsoft with Bing, Skype, etc. And of course Amazon has amazon.com, which is consuming a lot of resources as well, with all the video, music content, features and visitors. Google is the only company out of these 3, which started with the product that requires tons of resources - Search and it’s still the most important product for Google, and most visited web site. But Google is also crazily efficient with hardware usage (Large-scale cluster management at Google with Borg). I think Amazon has to use more hardware to achieve equal goals. So, could be equal to Google or bigger in size. And I don’t know where to put Microsoft, because it has search engine, chunk of cloud and tons of it’s own cloud based products. All 3 companies spent billions of dollars on data centers and keep building them. But the trick is that while they have to build DCs in advance, they can’t build much more than projected demand as it’s super expensive to operate them and there aren’t many places with resources to operate data center, like electricity, water, close transportation, educated specialists, etc. Now answering the question - I think it’s gotta be one of Amazon, Microsoft or Google, but which one - it’s a big secret. Even if there are people who could answer it, they can not do it.

World’s Largest Data Center If the word, world’s largest data center portrays ‘Range International Information Group Langfang, China’ then this information is for you. Switch, a globally recognized leader in future-proof data center design, superscale cloud, unparalleled telecom gateways and energy sustainability, has opened a large colocation facility in the Tahoe Reno Industrial Center in Nevada thus making it able to reach the top spot as the largest and the most advanced data center campus present in the world, neighboring Tesla’s Gigafactory. Surrounded by a 20-foot concrete wall it is also known as The Citadel Campus.  A spotlight on some facts · Location: Tahoe Reno Industrial Center · Energy Source: 100% Renewable · Type: Tier IV Mind-blowing numbers · Size: 2000 Acre campus · Data Center Space: 7.2 million sq.ft. · Power Requirement: 650 megawatts (MW) If the above is not enough to boggle your neurons, then here’s some more Switch is the only company with a 100-percent Clean Energy Index demonstrating Switch’s leadership in creating transparency and committing renewable source of power procurement. More Insights The data center is fitted with every advanced security feature that you can think of, the connectivity is backed by a 500-mile, multi-terabyte fiber optic network-the Superloop system to San Francisco and Los Angeles as well as the company’s 2.5 MN. sq.ft. of data center space situated in Las Vegas with 10Gbps circuits at less than 4ms latency. The facility’s power source is backed by a tri-redundant UPS system and has the potential of up to 42kW of power per cabinet. With such a huge facility and technologically advanced systems, Switch SuperNAP is now an apex predator of the data center universe.
